The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. H. has been engaged in this business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3000000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2006, H. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. H. has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell. H. is now requesting a new loan of 9000000 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. H. plans to use additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.use: Buy pigs.

loans.name: Faavevela

texts.en:
Faavevela F., 36, is married with 5 children. She has 4 years of experience in the fishing business. She sells to the village people/public 4 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD).

She had 2 previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are Faavevela’s only access to capital because she cannot qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She wants to use this loan to buy another fishing net, help pay for her children's school fees, and improve her home.

loans.use: Buy fishing supplies

loans.name: Mai Thi

texts.en:
Lâm Mai is a 34 year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoá. She is married and has two school-aged children. To making a living, Lâm raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Lâm has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3000000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2005, Lâm joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Lâm has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. Lâm is requesting a new loan of 9000000 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. Lâm plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family.

loans.use: Buy livestock.

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn M. V., 38 years old, is married to Luduvico an auto mechanic. Merlyn loves to engage in business. Previously, she engaged in various businesses like longganisa; dried fish and vegetables vending. But she earns only a little amount with those goods.

Presently, she is engaged in selling used clothing known as “ukay-okay” to earn a better income. She plans to have a display stand in the public market as she now only rents.

Merlyn hopes someday that she can expand her business and to have additional store outlets. She believes that PAGLAUM and KIVA will continually support micro-entrepreneurs like her.

loans.use: Expand clothing business.

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.en:
O. Phạm, 47, lives in the town of Hưng yên. She is married and has two school-aged children. To making a living, O. owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising cattle for sale. O. has been engaged in this business for over 20 years and earns approximately 2000000 VND a month from these activities.

In 1999, O. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. O. has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future.

O. is requesting a loan of 15000000 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. The loan will be the ninth taken out by O. from TYM Fund. O. plans to use the revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: Raisng

loans.name: Dao Thi

texts.en:
Khuê Đào, 57, lives in the town of Hưng yên. She is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Khuê owns and operates a business venture raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising cattle for sale. Khuê has been engaged in this business for over 20 years and earns approximately 2500000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2001, Khuê joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Khuê has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Khuê is requesting a new loan of 10000000 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. The loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Khuê from TYM Fund. Khuê plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: Buy livestock.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en:
Tuyết Nguyễn, 47, lives in the town of Hưng yên. She is married and has two adult children. To making a living, Tuyết owns and operates a business making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling pork products in the local community. Tuyết has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2000000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2004, Tuyết joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tuyết has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to expand the business. Tuyết is requesting a new loan of 15000000 VND which will be used to expand the business.

The loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Tuyết from TYM Fund. Tuyết plans to use the revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: Expand business.

loans.name: Shanna

texts.en:
Shanna O., 22, is married and has no children. She has 2 years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the village people/public 3 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).

She has no previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are Shanna’s only access to capital because she cannot qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan to buy more tools, a garden sprayer, and chemicals to improve her business.

loans.use: Purchase tools and chemicals for her plantation

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en:
X. Nguyễn, 54, lives in the town of Hưng yên. She is married and has three adult children. To make a living, X. owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. X. has been engaged in this business for over 30 years and earns approximately 2000000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2004, X. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. X. has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund. That loan was used to expand the business. X. is requesting a new loan of 15000000 VND which will be used to purchase breeding livestock.

The loan will be the fifth loan taken out by X. from TYM Fund. X. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: Buy breeding livestock.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en:
Cài Nguyễn, 43, lives in the town of Hưng yên. She is single and does not have any chlidren. To make a living, Cài owns and operates a business raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from cultivating fruit trees & harvesting fruit for sale. Cài has been engaged in this business for over 30 years and earns approximately 2000000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2001, Cài joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cài has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund, used to pay for services to increase crop yield. Cài is requesting a new loan of 10000000 VND which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. The loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Cài from TYM Fund. Cài plans to use the revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.use: Purchase seeds.

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.en:
L. Tran, 45, lives in the town of Hưng yên. She is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, L. owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising cattle for sale. L. has been engaged in this business for over 25 years and earns approximately 2000000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2004, L. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. L. has successfully repaid a previous L. from TYM Fund. This previous L. was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. L. is now requesting a new L. of 10000000 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell.

The L. will be the fifth taken out by the borrower from TYM Fund. L. plans to use the revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: Buy livestock feed and supplies.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en:
L. Nguyen, 38, lives in the town of Hưng yên. She is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, L. owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising chickens for sale. L. has been engaged in this business for over 12 years and earns approximately 2000000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2008, L. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and engage in business activities. L. has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund, used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. L. is requesting a loan of 9000000 VND to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. The loan will be the second taken out by L. from TYM Fund. L. plans to use the revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: Purchase livestock.

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.en:
T. Tran, 69, lives in the town of Hưng yên. She is widowed and has four adult children. To make a living, T. owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising ducks for sale. T. has been engaged in this business for over 40 years and earns approximately 2000000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2000, T. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. T. has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund, used to purchase breeding livestock. T. is requesting a loan of 10000000 VND, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. The loan will be her eigth loan from TYM Fund. T. plans to use the revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: Purchase livestock.

loans.name: Lynn

texts.en: Lynn A., 32, is a resident of Tinago, Ozamiz City.  She is a public school teacher and a micro-entrepreneur, married and has two children.  She is earning an income from her monthly salary as a teacher while her husband operates a motorcab for hire and sometimes drives for added income.  Lynn decided to engage in a Sari-Sari store business in their house and a barbeque vending during off time from school.  Now as an active member of PAGLAUM MPC and a second loaner, she is applying for PHP 7,000.00 to be used for additional capital. Lynn believes that PAGLAUM and KIVA will help her give her family a better future.

loans.use: Equip Sari-sari store,

loans.name: Vu Thi

texts.en:
Lịch Vũ, 50, lives in the town of Hưng yên. She is widowed and has two adult children. To make a living, Lịch owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising cattle for sale. Lịch has been engaged in this business for over 30 years and earns approximately 2000000 VND a month from these activities.

In 1997, Lịch joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lịch has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund, used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. Lịch is now requesting a new loan of 15000000 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. The loan will be her 10th from TYM Fund. Lịch plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: Purchase livestock.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en:
Gái Nguyễn, 51, lives in the town of Hiải Dương. She is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Gái owns and operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing cargo transport services to local community members. Gái has been engaged in this business for over 20 years and earns approximately 3000000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2002, Gái joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gái has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund, used to purchase breeding livestock. Gái is requesting a loan of 10000000 VND to purchase a transport vehicle to improve the business. The loan will be her sixth from TYM Fund. Gái plans to use the additional revenue from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: Purchase transport vehicle.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia O. M., 45, is an active member of PAGLAUM MPC-Ozamiz. A micro-entrepreneur, currently engaged in dealing relief goods locally known as “ukay-okay,” she has seven children and is a sole bread winner to her family. Lydia separated from her husband a year ago.

Lydia started her business in 1999 with only P1,800.00. Now her business grows bigger and she has her own stall to display her relief goods, at Agora public market, in the City of Ozamiz.

Now Lydia is applying for a loan of PHP 5,000.00 for additional capital. She is doubling her effort so she can give her children a better future. She also plans to expand her business. Lydia is thankful to PAGLAUM MPC for the savings habit she learned and for the insurance and other benefits she enjoys.

loans.use: Capital for "ukay-okay" (used clothing)  business.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en:
L. Nguyễn, 35, lives in the town of Hiải Dương. She is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, L. owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising seafood. L. has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 5000000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2002, L. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. L. has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund, used to purchase breeding livestock. L. is requesting a loan of 20000000 VND to purchase breeding livestock. The loan will be her sixth from TYM Fund. L. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: Buy breeding livestock.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en: Rosita P., 58, is married to Bienvinido, a farmer.  The couple is blessed with seven children and lives in Cebulin, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental.  Their source of income is from her husband.  Rosita decided to become a member of Paglaum Co-op to support the needs of her child who is in school.  She has applied for a PHP 10,000 loan to buy a pig, feed and vitamins.  Rosita wishes to improve their lives with her business.

loans.use: Buy pig , feed and vitamins.

loans.name: Phan Thi

texts.en:
Hựu Phan, 51, (right) lives in the town of Hiải Dương. She is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Hựu owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Hựu has engaged in this business for over 30 years and earns approximately 3000000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2007, Hựu joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Hựu has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund, used to purchase breeding livestock. Hựu is requesting a loan of 9000000 VND to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. The loan will be her second from TYM Fund. Hựu plans to use the additional revenue from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: Purchase livestock fed.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en:
Thưa Nguyễn, 35, lives in the town of Hiải Dương. She is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Thưa owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Thưa has engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3000000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2002, Thưa joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Thưa has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund, used to purchase breeding livestock. Thưa is requesting a loan of 20000000 VND to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. The loan will be her ninth from TYM Fund. Thưa plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: Buy livestock feed.

loans.name: Maura

texts.en: Maura Tac is a 67 years old widow who has four married children.  Hog raising is her project.  She became a member of Paglaum MPC, last September, 2008.  Maura is a good member who religiously paid her obligation to give her a good credit rating with the Co-op.  She is seeking a loan of PHP10,000.

loans.use: Buy pigs.

loans.name: Phan Thi

texts.en:
L. Phan is a 38-year-old woman living in the town of Hải Dương. She is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, L. owns and operates a business venture in the food sector, making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling liquor, such as beer and wine, in the local community. L. has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000,000 VND a month from this activity.

In 2004, L. joined TYM Fund in order to gain access to financial services, primarily to help improve her living conditions and her ability to engage in her business activities. L. has successfully repaid a previous L. from TYM Fund. This previous L. was used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings.

L. is now requesting a new L. of 20,000,000 VND, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. The L. will be the fourth L. taken out by this TYM Fund borrower. L. plans to use the additional revenue to improve her family's general standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en:
Thuý Nguyễn (0) is a 35-year-old female living in the town of Hiải Dương. She is married and has two school-age children. To make a living, Thuý owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Thuý has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2002, Thuý joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Thuý has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock.

Thuý is now requesting a new loan of 20,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. The loan will be the 6th loan taken out by the borrower from TYM Fund. Thuý plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell

loans.name: Alona

texts.en: Mrs. Alona C. is 35 years old, married and blessed with four children.  Her husband is a motorcab driver.  Alona manages their pottery business. She is a new member of Paglaum MPC.  She was loaned the amount of PHP 10,000 for additional capital for her business. She wishes that her pottery will progress and she will be able to sell and supply to any point of Mindanao.

loans.use: For purchase of clay and payment of labor

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Mrs. Julieta B. is recognized as a regular member of Paglaum MPC since she became a member in November 2002. She resides at Barangay Calaran, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. The whole family has membership in the co-op and are all MIGS members in good standing. Julieta has obtained previous loans and has never defaulted in their repayment.

This is her twelfth loan. She is very happy managing her sari-sari store and prays that someday she will be able to grow her business significantly. She is thankful to God that there is Paglaum MPC to offer financial assistance to people who want to change their lives from a state of financial hardship to a better standard of living.

loans.use: To gain additional capital from her sari-sari store by purchasing grocery items.

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Mrs. Joan L., 23 years old, is married and lives at Villaflor, Oroquieta City. Her source of income comes from her sand and gravel business. Her husband is very supportive of her; in fact, he’s the one who oversees the business from time to time. The couple desires to have a baby someday.

The business started when Joan became a member of Paglaum Multi-purpose Cooperative in September 2005. She thought that this business would be ideal for them because they are near the river bank. Financial Assistance was provided by the cooperative. She has obtained loans several times already.

Today, Joan applies for PHP 20,000 to pay the daily wages of the workers. In the future, the couple dreams of becoming the supplier of sand and gravel to a big construction company.

loans.use: To pay the salary of her workers

loans.name: Maria Fe

texts.en:
Maria Fe G. is 53 years old and a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative from Alegria, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. She is married and has 4 children. She is very industrious and takes great care raising her hogs while her husband is busy farming. Maria Fe personally manages their hog-raising business, which is doing well. She is a savvy business woman and the ups and downs of the business are normal to her. Sometimes they have business losses, sometimes a good return.

Now she sees a good opportunity to expand their business. She is requesting PHP 5,000 from Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative to buy animal feed and vitamins. She hopes deeply for a good education for her children and hopes to own a piggery someday.

loans.use: Purchase animal feed and vitamins

loans.name: Ruta

texts.en: Ruta L., 24, is married with one child.  She has three years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the village people and general public three days per week. She has had two previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 tala (~$120 US).  SPBD loans are Ruta’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan to buy more equipment and chemicals for the business and also to improve her home.

loans.use: To purchase garden spray, bush knife, and insectide

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma B. has been a member of the PMPC microfinance program for three years. She is married and has one child. This is her seventh loan, which is intended for additional capital for her massage and reflexology center as well as for her sari-sari store business. She engaged with these businesses to earn more income for her family.

She started her business with small capital and is very thankful for Paglaum MPC, which has let her borrow money to obtain additional capital for her business. She now earns a bigger income from her store as a result. She is also grateful to be able to extend massage and reflexology services in her neighborhood.

loans.use: To obtain additional capital for her sari-sari store and reflexology businesses.

loans.name: Teu

texts.en: Teu F., 28, is married with three children. She has four years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the village people and the public three days per week. She has had two previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD). SPBD loans are Teu’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan to buy equipment and chemicals for her business, as well as home improvements.

loans.use: Purchase garden spray, bush knife, and chemicals

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Mrs. Gloria L., 64, is married and lives in Pines, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is a single parent with one child. She has experienced difficulty being a single parent, but it's not a hindrance for her to move on. She found ways to survive, and opened a “sari-sari” (general store) with a loan from Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) in October 2000. She was able to manage the business successfully; in fact, it covers her daily consumption needs and also her child's allowance. Now, she is applying for a loan of PHP 14,000 to buy additional goods for her sari-sari store. She will be happy if she sees her child finish school.

loans.use: Buy additional goods for "sari-sari" store

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Mrs. Elizabeth C. has enjoyed more than a year of association with Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative, a partner through thick and thin for her business. Her primary source of income is selling used clothing. It’s a daily challenge for her to submit her loan payments on time, but this has now become a habit. Elizabeth is 57 years old, married, and has eight children. She tells us with pride that she is able to nurture all her children well. Finishing a degree was far out of sight for her and she only reached the fourth year high school. But, she’s happy that she was able to send her children to school. In fact, she has now children working abroad. She has applied with Paglaum MPC for a loan of PHP 40,000. With this loan she will purchase additional bundles of used clothing. She wants to expand her business by opening another used clothing store.

loans.use: Buy bundles of used clothing

loans.name: Caridad

texts.en: Mrs. Caridad S. is 61 years old and married to Asterio, a farmer. They have seven children, all of whom are married. Caridad started her business, a sari-sari store (mini grocery store), with a little capital she got from PMPC. She is a member in good standing and pays her dues promptly during their weekly center meetings. Recently, Caridad received another loan in the amount of PHP 10,000. She is very thankful to Paglaum and Kiva partners for the assistance, because it helps her a lot, especially in the daily financial needs of the family. She hopes to improve her family's status and continue the progress of her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks for her Mini Grocery Store

loans.name: Mary Cris

texts.en: Mrs. Mary Cris F. is 40 years old, married and lives in San Vicente Alto, Oroquieta City. She has three children. In light of the global crisis, her husband sought work, and eventually he was employed but far from his family. At first she experienced difficulty and had to make a big adjustment. In order to help her husband, she began to buy and sell fashion jewelry (silver). It was a good decision because she earns additional income. She got her capital from Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative. Most of her sales come from orders, so 98% is sold already. Aside from fashion jewelry, she is also a dealer of Natasha, MSE & Avon Products. Today, she is applying for a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy additional stock of fashion jewelry such as silver. Someday, she aims to have a store for fashion jewelry.

loans.use: Buy fashion jewelry

loans.name: Jinky

texts.en:
Mrs. Jinky G. is a resident of Barangay Tamban, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is married and blessed with one child. She has been an active member of Paglaum MPC since 2007. According to her, she is lucky to be one of the many patrons of the cooperative.
 
PMPC has helped her a lot in her project, which is house repairs. She has received a loan in the amount of PHP 5,000 to purchase housing materials and pay for labor. Being a co-op member, she knew that it gives her a lot of benefits. Jinky and her husband strive to make a living to be able to pay back the loan on time.
 
Now she wishes that through Paglaum MPC, their lives will change for the better.

loans.use: Purchase materials for house repairs and pay labor expenses

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en:
Mary Grace M. lives in the municipality of Hamtic in beautiful Antique Province. Antique is located on the island of Panay, which is situated in the west-central part of the Philippine archipelago. People say Antique is where "the mountains meet the sea"; its economy revolves around fishing and farming.

Mary Grace and her husband, Julito, raise carabao and cattle. Carabao--a kind of water buffalo that many consider to be the national animal--are usually used as farm work animals, and they also produce milk. Mary Grace plans to use this loan to buy two head of carabao, two head of cattle, and food supplements for her livestock. Besides livestock, Mary Grace also earns income by selling fruits and vegetables, and charcoal for cooking.

Mary Grace has five daughters and three sons; the youngest is six, and the oldest is 28. Her oldest daughter has a college education, and so far is the only one of her children to attain that level of education. Mary Grace says she hopes to be able to continue to support her children's education, and hopes they all find stable jobs so they can become independent and be happy. She also dreams of having enough money to be able to build a more durable house.

loans.use: To buy two head of carabao (water buffalo), two head of cattle, and livestock food supplement

loans.name: Nena

texts.en: Nena P. is of legal age, has three children, and lives in Salimpuno, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She has lived with her common-law husband for years. She started the business with her savings. She's been a member of Paglaum for almost three years now and she's on her seventh loan cycle, seeking PHP 14,900. With her previous loans, she displayed a good record of payment and has no defaults. At present, she is applying for a loan to buy additional stock such as laundry items, seasonings, goodies, toiletries and other household items. Some of the money will be used for the construction of her sari-sari store. She aims to have a successful business so her youngest child can finish her studies and have a good future.

loans.use: Sari-Sari store capital

loans.name: Nuñela

texts.en:
Nuñela M. lives in Culasi, Antique Province. Culasi is a coastal town at the northern end of Antique, and the mainstays of the local economy are fishing and farming. Nuñela, who is 75 years old, has run a business with her husband Juanito selling coconuts and charcoal for 18 years. They have a stall in the main public market in Culasi from which they sell fresh whole coconuts, ground coconut meat, and charcoal.

Nuñela plans to use the proceeds of this loan to buy a new grinder to process coconuts, and any money left over will be used as working capital to buy more fresh coconuts. The grinder is a rotary, electric tool attached to a table that makes it easy to extract coconut meat efficiently.

Nuñela hopes her business will continue to generate a stable income. She has been helping support her grandchildren's education, and says she never stops thinking about the welfare of her whole family.

loans.use: To buy a grinder for processing coconuts, and to purchase more coconuts

loans.name: Olympia

texts.en: Mrs. Olympia R. is 54 years old and lives in Rizal, Zamboanga del Norte. She is married to a businessman and they both operate their business. They have no children, but busy themselves with their business. They engage in copra-buying and hog-raising through their own small capital, and their customers are from neighboring Barangays. She is now seeking a loan in the amount of PHP 10,000 for capital as a copra buyer and to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. Her business is still stable and operating at this time. They are hoping that they can buy their own cargo truck for easy transport of copra.

loans.use: Additional capital for copra buying and to purchase feed for pigs

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
Adelaida D. is married and lives in Duyong, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She has two children, and they are both in elementary school.  

Currently she is seeking a loan in the amount of PHP 5,000 for the repair of their fishing boat. Sometimes, she and her husband have no catch, but sometimes they have a good harvest and they save a little from the sales.  

The couple wishes that to acquire another fishing boat so their income will grow bigger. It is also their utmost desire to send their children to college and establish a good life afterwards.

loans.use: Purchase materials for repair of fishing boat

loans.name: May

texts.en:
Mrs. May G. is 30 years old and married to Manuel, a farmer. They are blessed with two children. Their source of income is their vegetable garden, where they grow "kangkong" (swamp cabbage). Both husband and wife help each other to cultivate the garden and to sustain the needs of the family.

Mrs. G. is a good member of Kiva's partner Paglaum and seeks a loan amounting to PHP 7,000 for pesticides and for fertilizers. She is very thankful to Paglaum for the assistance with her projects. She hopes to have an abundant harvest always.

loans.use: To purchase chemicals and fertilizers for her garden

loans.name: Adolia

texts.en: Adolia B. is 54 years old and lives in Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is married with two children who are now working. Her husband is a tailor. She has been a member of Paglaum MPC since August 2007. She wants a loan for capital to expand her "carenderia" (restaurant) business. She deeply wishes for a good return on her business and to save for their old age.

loans.use: As capital to expand her carenderia

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en:
Loreta G. lives in Culasi, Antique Province. Culasi is a coastal town at the northern end of Antique, and the mainstays of the local economy are fishing and farming. Loreta has two daughters and a son, and is married to Edgar, a laborer. Loreta's son, a high school graduate, is 22 and the the eldest of her children; her two daughters, ages 18 and 15, are still attending high school.

Loreta has a business selling vegetables from a stall in Culasi's main public market. She also raises pigs for additional income. Loreta has been selling vegetables for about 10 years, and says that having the selection of vegetables that customers want is key to doing good business. She plans to use the proceeds of this loan as working capital, and is confident it will give her the flexibility to buy the right inventory at the right time.

Loreta's dream is for her children to be able to attend college. She wants them to be able to find good jobs, in the hopes that her children won't have to face the same challenges and hardships she has encountered in her life.

loans.use: To buy vegetables for resale at public market

loans.name: Mary Fe

texts.en:
Mary Fe B. is a resident of Calaran, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. Her husband works as a laborer and earns only a meager income. She registered as a regular member of Paglaum MPC February 19, 2009 and she is very responsible in giving her weekly obligation such as savings, share capital and insurance. She is toying with the hog raising business. In need of capital, she reached Paglaum for her project and applied for a loan of PHP 3,000. 

She is very thankful to Paglaum as her financing partner. She looks forward to seeing her piggery become successful.

loans.use: To buy additional heads of piglets and animal feed

loans.name: Jovita

texts.en:
Mrs. Jovita A. lives in Southern Poblacion, Baliangao, Mis. Occ.  She is a single mother with two children. Both of them already have jobs of their own.

She has been a member of Paglaum MPC since 2002.  According to her, Paglaum changed her life in almost all aspects because Paglaum taught her how to mingle with other people. She is inspired to continue her membership due to services that have been rendered by Paglaum, especially to the needy people. 

She has applied for a loan of PHP 20,000 for the expansion of her sari-sari store business. She said that the realization of her business was all because of Paglaum.  In addition to credit facilities, insurance, dividends and patronage refunds are just some of the benefits that she enjoys most being a member.  

She hopes that Paglaum will continue to help the poor, especially all her neighbors.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory such as noodles, canned goods, rice and other household items

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn D. lives in the municipality of Hamtic in beautiful Antique Province. Hamtic is situated to the south of Antique, and is bounded by mountains in one direction and the coast in the other. Evelyn is 38 years old and has two sons and two daughters. Her eldest child, a daughter, is 14 and attends high school; the other three children are still in primary school. Evelyn's husband Alexius is a driver.

Evelyn plans to use the money from this loan to buy inventory for her sari-sari store. "Sari-sari" is Tagalog for "various kinds" and the shops sell just that: an assortment of basic foodstuffs, beverages, and everyday commodities. The shops retail items in small units -- selling single cigarettes, for example. Sari-sari shops fill an important economic and social niche in Filipino life, especially in poor or rural areas; they often have chairs or a bench out front and act as neighborhood watering holes.

Evelyn dreams that one day perhaps she'll be able to grow her sari-sari store into a mini-mart. She hopes that her business will continue to provide her with the income necessary to support her children's education.

loans.use: To buy inventory for her small variety store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en: Mrs. Alma R. E. of P8 San Antonio, Ozamiz City is an active member of the PAGLAUM MPC. Her husband is a Government Employee as a Draftsman in the City Engineers Office. Even if her husband is regularly employed, supporting the studies of her children is hard to do. She was previously engaged in buying and selling prawns and a Prawn Hatchery operation but failed.  Presently, she is engaged in NFA rice retailing under the Tindahan Natin Program of the government. She started this business with an initial capital of P5,000.00 from her relatives and friends a year ago. Her customers were her neighbors and close friends. Now she is expanding by delivering her sacks of rice to different stores in their area and neighboring places in Mis. Occ. Now on her second loan, she is applying for PHP 10,000.00 for additional capital for her existing business. Her future plan is to establish an outlet in the city and to give continuous support for her children's education. These hopes and aspirations will come true with the help of KIVA and PAGLAUM.

loans.use: Additonal capital for NFA rice retailing business

location.town: P8 San Antonio, Ozamiz City, Mis. Occ.

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en: Estrella M. is a member of St. Vincent Center in Sibutad, Zamboanga del Norte. She has no record of defaults with her membership. Now, she is applying for a PHP 5,000.00 loan for her hog raising business. Her loan is intended to buy feed and vitamins. She hopes that her business will grow. Her husband industriously tills their rice field. They are blessed with one child who is now studying in college. She said that with the help of her business she can provide the school needs of her child.

loans.use: To purchase feed and vitamins

loans.name: Tita

texts.en: Mrs. Tita M. of Purok Bonifacio, Bacolod, Ozamiz City is a new member of PDP-LP Microfinance Program. She is 36 years of age, with five sons and one daughter. They have twins who are boys. Her husband is a carpenter. With the help and idea of her friend, she decided to engaged in the RTW buy and sell business in order to help her husband support their family. For the past year, her business has been growing with her neighbors and friends as her loyal customers. She is very happy being a member of PAGLAUM because of the services and insurance she enjoys. Now she is applying for a loan of PHP 3,000.00 to add to her capital for her RTW buy and sell business. She is hoping that someday she will own a house and a lot and be able to expand her business. She believes that KIVA and PAGLAUM are continually reaching those micro-entrepreneurs like her to improve the quality of living.

loans.use: Additional capital for her RTW buy & sell business

loans.name: Jovita

texts.en:
Paglaum MPC was created to run programs and offer services to those who need financial assistance and to provide business training. Jovita B. became a member of Paglaum on April 2008.

Jovita lacks financial capital for her sari-sari store. (The word sari-sari is Tagalog for "various kinds"). Jovita only had enough money to build the sari-sari. She is requesting PHP 14,900 to buy additional goods for sale. She is thankful that she can earn additional income for her family aside from her husband.

Jovita hopes to expand her sari-sari to a mini grocery store and to have a house of their own for the family.

loans.use: Buy additonal goods for sari-sari store

loans.name: Lucinda

texts.en:
Lucinda A. lives in the municipality of Bugasong in beautiful Antique Province. Antique is a coastal, mountainous province on the west side of the island of Panay; its economy is heavily dependent on fishing and farming. Lucinda is 65 years old and is married to Salvador, who is a farmer. They do not have any children.

Lucinda started her business selling dried saltfish and shrimp paste at market only recently. She found initial support for her endeavor when she became a member of Kiva partner Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) in 2008, and is now on her second loan cycle.

She plans to use the proceeds of this loan to buy more fishing materials, including rope, nets, floats and weights, and nylon line. Lucinda processes the fish she catches, drying them for sale at public market.

She hopes to generate enough income from her business to be able to help support her nephews' education. She also wants to save money in order to be financially stable when she and her husband are no longer able to work. Lucinda's ambition will help her achieve these goals: she wants to buy a motorized fishing boat some day, and plans to further expand her fishing operation.

loans.use: Fishing supplies such as rope, nets, weights and floats, and nylon line.

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Mrs. Julieta S., 62, is married with 2 children. She lives in Mobod, Oroquieta City, and started her snack vending business from capital of just PHP3,000. Her husband, who is a pensioner, is very supportive of her business.

The small business has been doing so well that she is confident to expand. She joined Paglaum MPC for the chance to receive loans. She is applying for PHP 8,000 to buy food for her snack vending. She envisions acquiring a stall in the public market. She also dreams of renovating the family's little house. Mrs S. in on the left in the photo.

loans.use: Buy additional food for snack vending

loans.name: Percita

texts.en:
Mrs. Percita S. is 39 years old and married. She lives at San Isidro, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She has 5 children. After she heard news about Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative, she got interested in it; that’s why she joined the co-op in October 2008.

She has staredt a retail clothing business. She is appying for a PHP 10,000 loan to buy additional ready-made clothing. She’s happy that she can implement her project because the cooperative will finance her. She hopes her business will be more profitable, and that she will see all her children finish their studies.

loans.use: to buy additional retail wear  for sale

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Mrs. Teresita M. D. P. of P1 Bacolod, Ozamiz City is a mother of 6. Four of her children are in school. She is hard working, and has been engaged in snack vending and barbeque vending since 2000. Aside from this business, she is also cultivating a little vegetable garden in their yard. Her husband is a carpenter.

As a new member of PDP-LP Program of Paglaum MPC, she enjoys the benefits of savings and insurances. Now she's applying for a loan of PHP 3,000 to buy ingredients for her barbeque and snack vending business, additional utensils and for the purchase of fertilizer for her garden. Her aspiration is to give her children a better future, make a mini carenderia (a local eatery) and expand her business in other areas.

loans.use: Additional capital for barbeque and snack vending

location.town: Purok 1 Bacolod, Ozamiz City, Mis. Occ.

loans.name: Gena

texts.en:
Mrs. Gena D., 32, is married and lives in Tawi-tawi, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. When she learned about Paglaum MPC, she became a member in July 2008 so that she could get help to set up her business. She used her first loan of PHP 3,000 to buy one piglet and this is how she started her hog-raising business.

She is grateful to God that her hog-raising business has done very well and she has buyers already. Now she is requesting a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy feed and more piglets. She also wants to build a concrete piggery for her pigs.

loans.use: to buy feed and more piglets to raise.

loans.name: Damiana

texts.en:
Damiana P. is a 64 year-old woman and happily married. Her husband is a laborer. They were blessed with nine children. Damiana is already on her fourth loan cycle. Her business is a “sari-sari” (general) store of which her primary customers are students, municipal employees, and also the folks of the neighboring barangays. Her business is growing and customers are increasing.

She has requested a loan amounting to PHP 7,000 hoping that this will help her in purchasing additional grocery items and meeting the existing needs of her present customers. Damiana believes that the business could grow larger and more stable in the future if it is managed correctly. She’s so thankful for Paglaum’s existence in the community and its program components that helped them realize the significance of patience and hard work.

loans.use: To buy additional goods for "sari-sari" store

loans.name: Esterlina

texts.en:
Mrs. Esterlina M. is married to a carpenter. The couple is blessed with two children, both in school. Esterlina became a member of Paglaum MPC in July 2005. She has had previous loans from Paglaum MPC usually for additional capital for her Junk Buying that she started long ago. She is now on her eighth loan, this one for Php 7,000. She will use her present loan to purchase junk items such as metals, plastics, aluminum etc.

The couple wishes to have a junk shop. She wants all her children to finish their courses. She is very grateful that she's one of the members of PMPC and has an opportunity to use Kiva services too.

loans.use: To buy junk items such as metals, plastics, aluminum etc.

loans.name: Luzira Posta Namuli Annet Group

texts.en:
Ms. N. Annet is a single mother, 36 years old, with 3 children: two boys and one girl aged 20, 17, and 14 years respectively. They are all going to school.

She has been running a boutique (trousers, shirts, skirts, blouses, jeans, suits, dresses) for over four years. She is using the loan to purchase more new and used clothes to enlarge her boutique business. She dreams of constructing rental houses.

loans.use: To buy more new and used clothes for her boutique

loans.name: Kikiafu 3 Group Amina Ali

texts.en:
A. Ali is married with five children, three of them in school. She owns a hairdressing salon for cutting and shaving hair. She is using the loan to purchase salon equipments like shavers, a fan, and combs.

She is thinking of starting another hairdressing salon specifically for ladies.

loans.use: To purchase equipment for her hairdressing salon

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana M., the 46-year-old mother of three children, is married to a fisherman. Because living on only her husband’s income has been very difficult, and given that the education of their children is a priorty, Ana decided to enter the rug business in partnership with other women in their barangay. Weaving with embroidery made of “bunot” (coco fiber), the rugs they produce are known in neighboring towns because of their uniqueness and quality.

It all comes down to a matter of "diskarte" (strategies) on how to live life, and Ana believes that one has to work hard and make sacrifices. Having become a member of Paglaum MPC in July of 2007, she and her partners hope that the organization will always be there for them in times of need. Today, Ana is requesting a loan of PHP 7,500 to buy materials for rug-making. To put up a decent home and have her children established in their own careers is the dream of the M. family.

loans.use: To buy additional materials for rug-making.

loans.name: Kikiafu 3 Group Mariam Nalubowa

texts.en: Ms. Mariam N., a 40-year-old single woman with five children all attending school, has been selling clothes for over 10 years. She is requesting the loan to buy more clothing such as Gomes’s to sell. She has managed to handle challenges herself and her dream is to buy a plot of land and construct a residential house.

loans.use: To buy more clothing such as Gomes’s to sell.

loans.name: Kikiafu 2 Omoding Joyce Group

texts.en: Ms. O. Joyce is a married woman, age 36, with six kids: three girls and three boys. The first born is 19 and the last born is  2 years old. Five are going to school and one is still too young. She is using the loan to purchase millet and maize flour for the local brew. Her dream is to educate her kids.

loans.use: To purchase millet and maize flour for the local brew.

loans.name: Kikiafu 2  Acen Rebecca Group

texts.en: Ms. A. Rebecca is a single woman, age 39 years, with two kids: a girl and a boy, age 14 and 10 years respectively. She has been selling local brew for over nine years. She is using this loan to purchase yeast, millet and maize flour to make local brew which seems to be improving. She would like to have livestock if all goes well.

loans.use: To purchase yeast, millet and maize flour to make local brew

loans.name: Dina

texts.en:
Dina G. L. engages in snack making like puto (steamed rice cakes), siopao (steamed buns), siakoy (sugar twist), butchi (sticky rice balls), empanada and others. Every day, she peddles the snacks in their neighborhood and nearby villages to earn some income.

Dina is 39-years old, married and blessed with five children. Her husband has no work and she is the only one who generates income for the family's daily needs. She lives in Purok de Oro, Zone 3, Barangay Poblacion, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte in Southern Philippines.

Dina needs additional capital to meet the increasing demand of the market and to provide greater scope for her business. She is requesting a loan of 7000 PHP to purchase additional ingredients and materials for her business. If granted, this will be her second loan with Kiva's partner, HSPFI.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients and materials for snack business

location.town: Zone 3, Poblacion, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Kikiafu 2 Nasim Kigere Group

texts.en:
Ms. Nasim K. is 36 years old and married with four kids: two girls and two boys. All her kids go to school.

Nasim has owned a school canteen for over two years. She will use this loan to improve her business selling eatables, like bread, fresh juice, soda, cakes, chapatti, madasi, and sweets. She desires to buy more equipment, like the refrigerator for cold drinks.

loans.use: To buy more equipment for her canteen.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou C. is 49 years old and a resident of Zone 10, Bagong Silang, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte in Southern Philippines. She is married and blessed with three children. Two of her children are employed and the youngest is in college. Her husband works as painter in their arts and sign business, which they named AD Ventures Arts and Sign.

Due to financial needs, Marilou is applying for a loan of Php 7000 from KIVA partner HSPFI. She will use the loan to purchase additional materials for the business. It will help them generate more income and meet the demands and needs of their customers. If granted, this will be Marilou's second loan. She has always dreamed of putting up another branch in their hometown.

loans.use: To purhcase materials for her arts and sign business.

location.town: Zone 10, Bagong Silang, Iligan City, Lanao del Nor

loans.name: Kikiafu 1 Achi Prossy Group

texts.en: Prossy A. is 34 years old and married a 14 year old daughter, who is going to school. Prossy will use this loan to improve her business selling used clothes, specifically ladies skirts, blouses, and dresses. She has been in her business for over five years. She is hardworking and encouraging, and believes she will see a change in her business.

loans.use: To improve her business selling used clothing.

loans.name: Ma. Theresa

texts.en:
Ma. Theresa P. is 44 years old and a resident of Zone 12, Bunawanon, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte in Southern Philippines. She is married to Iriño P., a farmer. They are blessed with nine children, one of whom is married.

Marites (her nickname) buys bananas and sells them in the market place. Currently, her business is good but due to the demands of her customers, she wants to purchase additional stock. She is applying for a loan of Php 4000 from KIVA partner HSPFI to purchase the additional bananas. This will be her first loan cycle.

loans.use: To purchase bananas for sale.

location.town: Zone 12, Bunawan, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase material for bitegi, uniforms for school children.

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en: Adwoa K. is a widow with 6 dependents. She is a food trader and has sold fried plantains and beans in Siwdo for 15 years.  Adwoa uses her income to pay for her family’s expenses, especially food.  She will use the loan to add capital to her business so that she can buy more food to sell, which in turn would help to increase her profit. Adwoa plans to reinvest any newly generated income back into her enterprise to ensure continued success.

loans.use: To buy more food for resale

loans.name: Dante

texts.en:
Dante A. is married with 4 children and received an education through junior high school. Dante works in Siwdo as an electrician and also sells electrical parts, which he has done for 10 years. His wife works in the same area as a trader selling banku (also known as kenkey, dumplings served with soup or stew). Dante uses his income to pay for his family’s expenses, such as food, school fees, and bills.

Dante will use the loan to purchase additional electrical parts for sale and also enhance his repair works. With the new profits from his expanded business, Dante plans to reinvest in his enterprise for continued success.

loans.use: To increase inventory.

loans.name: Faraji

texts.en: Faraja Mhidin is a Tanzanian business married man. He runs a photo studio at Yombo Vituka in Dar es Salaam. He produces all types of photos including passport size. He purchases business materials from Kariakoo Photo studio shops in whole and retail sales. He has been in the business for four years and he has been our client for seven years. He is requesting a loan of 1,200,000 Tanzanian Shillings to buy more business materials to meet his customers' demand.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Kikiafu 1 Anyuru Vicky Group

texts.en: Ms. A. Vicky is aged 38 years, married with 4 children, 1 girl and 3 boys who all go to school. She will use her share of this group loan to purchase items in bigger volume for her retail shop, that is bags of sugar, groundnuts, beans, and maize flour and jerricans of cooking oil. She has owned a retail shop for over 6 years and she dreams of buying land where she will construct rental houses.

loans.use: To increase inventory.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes K. is a Tanzanian woman microentrepreneur. She has two business: a traditional clothing sales shop (selling kanga and vitenge) and poultry keeping at Lumo ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases clothes from Mnazi Mmoja traditional clothing wholesale shopping center and sells retail to her customers. She keeps both broilers and layers in her poultry cages. She has been in business for three years .Her business income is used to meet her family's daily demands and for capital. She is requesting a loan of 1,200,000 Tanzania shillings to boost up the business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Hidaya

texts.en: Hidaya B. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur. She runs a business selling traditional clothes (kanga and vitenge) at Mbagala ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases the clothes from Mnazi Mmoja traditional clothes shopping center, from the wholesale shops, and sells retail to customers at Mbagala. She has been in the business for five years. She needs to borrow 1,200,000 Tanzania shillings to buy more business items to meet the demand.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for retail

loans.name: Ketifalawo D Nasalo Shamimu Group

texts.en: Ms. N. Shamimu is a single lady aged 25 years with 2 children, 1 schooling and another one young with 3 dependents. She will use her share of this group loan to sell used clothes, sandals, and air time. She has been in her business for a year now. There has been a positive change in her business.

loans.use: To increase inventory.

loans.name: Akua

texts.en: Akua M. is a trader in Siwdo, who sells footwear such as slippers and gari, a grain-like food that is popular in Ghana. Gari is made from cassava, which is peeled, milled into a starch and then fried.  The end product, gari,  is ready for consumption.  Akua has been selling gari for 10 years. She is a widow with 2 children, who she supports. Her loan will be used to buy more gari, which is in high demand in the area, and to buy more slippers for resale. She hopes to increase her profit, which she will reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To buy more gari and to purchase slippers for resale.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam A. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur married woman. She runs a café at Buguruni ward in Dar es Salaam.  She sells different types of food in her café and soft drinks.  The income generated from the business is used to meet her family's daily demands. She plans to extend her business. She needs a loan of 800,000 Tanzania shillings to boost up the business.

loans.use: To invest in cafe

loans.name: Ketifalawo D  Nalwaga Annet Group

texts.en: Ms. Annet N. is a 24-year-old single lady. She is using this loan to buy cosmetics: hair chemicals,  jelly, glycerin, shampoo, lotions, cream, etc. She has been in her business for two years. She is not stressed in spite of the changes now happening. She plans to purchase land and construct a house.

loans.use: To buy hair chemicals, jelly, glycerin, shampoo, lotions, cream etc.

loans.name: Zuhura

texts.en:
Zuhura D. is a poultry keeper. She runs the business at Yombo Buza ward in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania.

She keeps both broilers and layers in her poultry cages. Broilers take only four months to be sold, but layers take six months to produce the first eggs. During the first six months a lot of funds are consumed for treatment and feeding. Thus, income from selling the broilers is used to meet the cost of raising the layers.

Zuhura needs a loan of Tshs 800,000 to extend the business by constructing more poultry cages and buying more chicks.

loans.use: To construct more poultry cages and buy more chicks

loans.name: Ketifalawo D Nakimuli Rose Group

texts.en: Mrs. Rose N. is a married woman, age 40, with five kids and four other dependents. Mrs. Rose N. owns a retail shop selling sugar, maize flour, wheat flour, rice, cooking oil, tea leaves, soap and cosmetics. She has been in this business for two years. She is using this loan to purchase more stock as she wants to enlarge her business.

loans.use: To purchase more stock

loans.name: Nassoro

texts.en:
Nassoro J. is a micro-entrepreneur and a Tanzanian business man. He runs a pharmacy called Pharmacy Partimo at Mbagala ward in Dar es Salaam. He saves a lot of the people of Mbagala because there is no dispensary available. He purchases the business items from Kariakoo Wholesale Pharmacy.

He is requesting a loan of Tshs 1,400,000 to buy more business items.

loans.use: To buy more items for his pharmacy

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
For ten years, Abena W. has been a trader selling food items like peanuts and beans in Siwdo. She buys them in sacks and distributes to her costumers. She is currently out of stock and her warehouse is almost empty. She plans to buy more food items soon.

Abena is married with three children and her husband is a farmer. Abena is responsible for paying some of her family’s expenses, especially the task of providing food for the entire household. She requires this loan so that she can to afford to go to Techiman, a distant town where foodstuffs are cheaper. She will purchase more goods in bulk for resale. Abena hopes to reinvest the new profits from her business and also to use them to take care of her family.

loans.use: To purchase more food items in bulk for resale

loans.name: Cloud

texts.en:
Cloud M. is married and is a Tanzanian micro-businessman. He runs a double business at Yombo Vituka ward in Dar es Salaam. He runs a photo studio and a clothing shop.

He purchases his business items in the Kariakoo City business center from the photo studio shops and clothing wholesale shops. He sells to retail customers in Yombo Vituka.

He is requesting a loan of Tshs 1,400,000 to buy more business items to meet his customers’ needs.

loans.use: To purchase more items for his photo and clothing businesses

loans.name: Mwanahamis

texts.en: Mwanahamis I. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur, selling clothes at Lumo in Vituka ward. She is a married woman with three children in school: one is at university and the other two are in secondary school. She purchases clothes from Karume, in a small city market, and sells retail to customers in Lumo. Her business income is used to pay the children's school fees and meet the daily family needs. She needs a loan of 800,000 Tanzania shillings to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Katale Bwaise Kakembo Nuru Group

texts.en:
Mrs. K. Nuru is 45 years old, married with four children, and looking after two orphans. All are going to school.

She has owned a pharmacy selling medicine for over 10 years. She is using the loan to add various types of medicine to her pharmacy. She wishes to get whatever she needs and to help others too.

loans.use: To purchase medicines for her pharmacy

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace N. is married and is a Tanzanian microbusinesswoman. She runs a business selling charcoal at Kiwani ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases the charcoal wholesale direct from the producers and sells to retail customers. Charcoal is a main source of fuel for cooking in most of the developing countries due to the unreliability and high cost of electricity.

Grace needs a loan of Tshs 1,200,000 to extend her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business

loans.name: Katale Bwaise Nantogo Sylivia Group

texts.en:
Mrs. N. Sylivia is a married woman, aged 38 years, with five children: three still in school and two dependents.

Mrs. Sylivia is using the loan to purchase wines, beer, bottled water and sodas. She has been in her business for over 10 years and now she is happy for the Kiva loan because it is increasing her stock and, more so, her profits. Her dream is to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase wines, beer, bottled water and sodas for her business

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce A. is married with three children. She received an education through junior-high school. For one year, Joyce has worked as a trader in Siwdo, selling fresh goods such as garden eggs and tomatoes. Her husband also works as a trader in the same area.

Joyce uses her income to pay for her family’s expenses, such as the household bills. She will use the loan to purchase additional foodstuffs for selling. With the new profits from her expanded business, Joyce plans to reinvest back in to her enterprise to ensure her further success.

loans.use: To purchase additional foodstuffs for selling

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena N. is divorced and has five children. She is a trader in Accra selling, primarily, plantains to her customers. She is a fairly new businesswoman having started her enterprise in 2006. Abena uses her income to pay for the utilities and bills and feeding her family.

Abena will use the loan to purchase more plantains to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to increase her capital which will further increase her profits.

loans.use: To purchase more plantains to sell

loans.name: Kambona

texts.en: Kambona U. is a married Tanzanian businessman with four school-aged children: two in secondary education and the rest in primary school. He runs a business selling soft drinks wholesale. He is an agent for Coca-Cola Company. He also runs a pub from which he sells a variety of drinks, including alcoholic drinks. He is in need of a loan of 1,400,000 Tanzania shillings to extend his business.

loans.use: To purchase more goods

loans.name: St Francis A Kabatanya Florence Group

texts.en:
Ms. K. Florence is a single woman, age 42, with three children: two girls and one boy, plus one dependent. All attend school.

She owns a grocery store that has sold charcoal and bananas for one year so far. She is using the loan to purchase charcoal and bananas wholesale which has increased her stock and, more so, her profits.

She loves serving her community by supplying charcoal and bananas and trying to reduce on the transportation costs. Her dream is to construct a house.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal and bananas wholesale

loans.name: St. Francis A Kanyike Sarah Group

texts.en: Mrs. Sarah K. is a widow, age 48, with six kids (four still in school) and three orphans also in school. She will use the loan to purchase charcoal and water wholesale. She can't forget how hard it was when she started the business on her own. She thanks God that Kiva is serving as an instrument to sustain her business. Her dream is to see all the children she’s looking after grow up well.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal and water wholesale

loans.name: St. Francis A  Aliyiza Lydia Group

texts.en: Mrs. Lydia A. is a married woman, age 34, with two kids: a 14-year-old son and a 6-year-old daughter,  both in school. For over two years, she has been selling dry cells, books, toothpaste, sweets, pens and pencils, torches, and small wine packs. She will use the loan to buy more stock. Her dream is to enlarge her business, own poultry and see her kids through school.

loans.use: To purchase goods for sale

loans.name: Ally

texts.en:
Charcoal is the main source of fuel in most of the developing countries due to high cost and unstable supply of electricity.

Ally M. is a micro-businessman who runs a charcoal business at Buguruni ward in Dar es Salaam. He purchases the charcoal wholesale direct from the producers and sells to retail customers at Buguruni.

He is requesting a loan of Tshs 800,000 to buy more charcoal so as to meet his business demand.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional oil, fish and other foodstuffs for cooking and selling

loans.name: Helena

texts.en:
Helena O. works as a trader in Siwdo where she cooks a local food called banku (made from fermented corn/cassava dough) and sells it along the street. She has been in business for 6 years.

She is divorced with three children and received an education through junior high school. She is responsible for paying her family’s expenses such as school fees and bills.

Helena’s loan will be used to purchase more products and ingredients which she will use in making a greater quantity of banku for selling. She hopes to use the new profits to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: To purchase more products and ingredients for making banku

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Eric A., a woodworker, is married with five children. For two years, Eric has sold plywood and furniture in Siwdo. He received an education through junior high school. His wife is also employed as a trader in the area.

Eric uses his income to help support his family, primarily by paying bills and school fees. He will use this loan to purchase additional wood that he may either sell or use to make furniture. Eric plans to reinvest the new profits from his expanded business back into his trade.

loans.use: To purchase additional wood to sell or use to make furniture

loans.name: Yaw

texts.en: For five years, Yaw A. has worked as a trader selling beverages and clothing in Siwdo.  He is married with four children and received an education through senior high school. His wife also works as a trader in the area.  Yaw is responsible for supporting his family by paying school fees, supplying clothing for his children and also paying the family’s bills. He will use this loan to increase the quantity of clothing he sells so as to increase his profit. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to reinvest back into his trade and expand his enterprise.

loans.use: To increase stock of clothing to sell

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en: Adwoa A., a fishmonger, is married with two children. She has sold fried fish at Siwdo since 2004. Her husband is employed as a teacher. She received an education through junior high school.  Adwoa uses her income to pay for her family’s basic needs such as food and also her children’s school fees. Adwoa will use this loan to purchase additional fish for selling. With the increased profits, she will pay for her children’s school fees; thereby securing their education and future.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish for selling

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence A. is a trader selling food items and food she cooks in Siwdo, which she has done since 2007. She is married with 6 dependents and received an education through primary school. While Florence works as a trader, her husband is employed as a mason. She is responsible for paying for her family’s various needs, including food.

Florence’s loan will be used to purchase additional foodstuffs and ingredients for resale and also for the food she prepares for sale. She hopes to use her increased profits to further contribute to the capital of her business.

loans.use: Food used for resale and as ingredients in cooked products

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn has been operating a sari-sari store (a community-based store) in her village for more than the 20 years since she got married. She is married to Romeo and they were gifted with two children: Ryan, 24 years old, a graduate of a two-year vocational course in automotives and Rhey Jay, 19 years old, a college student. According to Marilyn, she is proud that her children grew up with discipline and respect.

She is now requesting a loan amounting to 11,000 Philippine Pesos to be used buying more groceries for her store. She is really striving to the best of her ability to succeed in this kind of business. She dreams for her youngest child to finish his studies and find a good job some day. “Trust in the Lord with all your heart, with all your soul, with your entire mind, and with all your strength so you will be helped by Him”, said Marilyn.

loans.use: To buy groceries for resale

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma is engaged in the vending business. She sells vegetables, fish, meat, and other groceries in her village with her small stall. In order to have additional capital for her business, she requested a loan amounting to 13,000 Philippine Pesos to improve her business. The loan will be used in buying more goods that she can offer to her customers.

She dreams that, by providing her children with the quality education that they will need to find a job, they will have a successful life when they finish their studies. She is convinced that she can send them to school by being patient and diligent in her enterprise.

Vilma is 49 years old and married to Amour, a government employee. They have three children: Kenneth Joy, 22 years old, a nursing graduate; Kennedy, 18 years old, a graduate of Hotel and Restaurant Management; and Karla Jane, the youngest at 15 years old, who will be a college student next school year. Vilma has a good family bond and is happy to enjoy the simplest way of life.

loans.use: To increase store inventory

loans.name: Doris

texts.es: Doris tiene 56 años, vive con su hija mayor en su casa propia. Trabaja día a día en la crianza de su ganado vacuno y ovino desde hace varios años atrás, pero hace un año implementó una granja de cerdos que vende periódicamente en la feria ganadera de su zona. Para tener buenas ganancias sus animales tienen que tener buen peso y esto se logra a base de una buena alimentación, por lo que pastea a sus animales todas las mañanas a una distancia de 3 horas de caminata de su casa y regresa en horas de la tarde. Para Doris esta actividad suele ser una distracción porque ella va al campo a respirar aire puro y está acostumbrada a esa rutina. Para más adelante, espera incrementar la cantidad de animales para tener mayor capital de trabajo. Es la segunda vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP, está muy dispuesta a  seguir trabajando por el bienestar de su  familia y también de los demás integrantes de su banco comunal. El dinero que está solicitando es para invertirlo en la compra de más ovejas y cerdos.
texts.en:
Doris is 56 years old and lives with her oldest daughter in her own home. She has worked day to day, breeding cattle and sheep for several years, but a year ago she started a pig farm that she periodically sells in the livestock fair in her region. In order to have good earnings, her animals have to have a good weight. This is achieved through good nutrition, for which she grazes her animals every morning at a distance of 3 hours by foot from her home. She returns in the afternoon. For Doris, this activity is usually a distraction because she goes to the countryside to breathe fresh air, and she is accustomed to this routine. For the future, she hopes to increase the quantity of animals in order to have more working capital. This is the second time that Doris has had a loan with MFP. She is very determined to continue working for the well-being of her family and also of the other members of her community bank. The money the she is asking for is to be invested in the purchase of more sheep and pigs.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sheep and pigs

loans.name: Elisabeth

texts.es: Elisabeth tiene 52 años, vive con su esposo y sus 2 hijos en su casa propia. Se dedica a la venta de frutas que trae de sus viajes a la selva y las vende en su localidad al por menor, repartiendo a sus clientes, y del mismo modo lleva de su localidad productos nativos  para venderlos en la selva. En algunas ocasiones realiza un intercambio de productos, Elisabeth viene desarrollando esta actividad desde hace 5 años y ha visto las ganancias y los resultados de este trabajo que le han permitido solventar los gastos familiares de su casa. Para más adelante quiere crecer en su negocio incrementando su capital. Es la primera vez que viene solicitando un préstamo con MFP, fue invitada a formar parte de su banco comunal porque vieron en ella a una persona responsable y dispuesta a realizar un trabajo en equipo. Con el dinero requerido comprará más mercadería, específicamente sacos de granos para venderlos en la selva, y allá comprará frutas.
texts.en:
Elisabeth is 52 years old and lives with her husband and her 2 children in their own home. She sells fruits that she brings from her trips to the forest and sells them in her town, distributing them to her clients. In the same manner, she brings native products from her town to sell in the forest. On some occasions, she exchanges the products. Elisabeth has been developing this activity for 5 years and has seen the earnings and results of this work, which have allowed her to settle her household expenses. In the future, she would like to grow her business and increase her capital. This is the first time the she has requested a loan with MFP. She was invited to be a part of her community bank because they saw in her a responsible person who was ready to work in a team. With the money she requested, Elisabeth will buy more merchandise, specifically sacks of grains to sell in the forest, and there, she will buy more fruit.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more merchandise

loans.name: Leoncio

texts.es: Leoncio tiene 55 años, es viudo y vive con su hija en su casa propia. Desde hace 4 años se dedica al transporte de pasajeros en motocarro, recorre todas las calles  de su localidad ofreciendo este servicio a todas las personas que le soliciten. Se levanta temprano para poder captar más clientes, de esta manera obtener los ingresos necesarios para solventar los gastos de los estudios del menor de sus hijos. Leoncio está muy pendiente del estado de funcionamiento de su movilidad, pues de ello depende su buen trabajo, actualmente hay gran demanda de este servicio, y aunque han aumentando los motocarros en su zona, él sigue trabajando confiado en su capacidad para superar la competencia. Para el futuro, Leoncio está pensando adquirir otra movilidad del mismo tipo que pueda alquilar a otro chofer e incrementar sus ganancias. Es la primera vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP, fue invitado a formar parte de su actual equipo porque conocen de su persona y tiene buenas referencias de él. Por su parte, Leoncio se compromete a ser un compañero más que aporte positivamente a su banco comunal. El dinero que está solicitando es para la compra de un nuevo cobertor para su movilidad y pagar el manteniendo de su motor.
texts.en:
Leoncio is 55 years old, is a widow, and lives with his daughter in his own house. For 4 years, he has dedicated himself to transporting passengers in a “motocarro” [a vehicle with 3 wheels].
